hyp: when she was 14 years old, lois went on a canoe trip. she'd only been on overnights before. this was to be a long one, into the trackless wilderness, as kapi put it. it was lois's first canoe trip on her last. kapi was the head of the summer camp to which lois had been sent ever since she was nine. camp manitou, it was called. it was one of the better ones for girls, though not the best. girls of her age whose parents could afford it were routinely packed off to such camps which bore a generic resemblance to one another. they favored indian names and had hearty, energetic leaders who were called kapi, skip, or scotty. at these camps, you learned to swim well, and sail, and paddle a canoe, and perhaps ride a horse or play tennis. when you weren't doing these things, you would do arts and crafts and turn out dingy, lumpish clay ashtrays for your mother. mothers smoked more back then, or bracelets made of colored braided string. cheerfulness was required at all times, even at breakfast. loud shouting and banging of spoons on the table were allowed, and even encouraged at ritual intervals. chocolate bars were rationed to control tooth decay and pimples. at night, after supper, in the dining hall or outside around the mosquito-infested campfire ring for special treats, there were sing-songs. louis can still remember all the lyrics to my darling clementine and to my bonnie lies over the ocean, while with acting out gestures, a rippling of the hands for the ocean, two hands together under the cheek for lies. she will never be able to forget them, which is a sad thought. lois thinks she can recognize women who went to these camps and who were good at it. they have a hardness to their handshakes, even though a way of standing, legs planted firmly apart, further than usual, a way of sizing you up to see if you'd be any good in a canoe. the front, not the back. they themselves would be in the back. they would call it the stern. she knows that such camps still exist, although camp manitou does not. they are one of the few things that haven't changed much. they now offer copper enameling and functionless pieces of stained glass broken into electric ovens. though judging from the productions of her friend's grandchildren, their artistic standards have not improved. to lois, encountering it in the first year after the war, camp manitou seemed almost ancient. its log-sided buildings with the white cement in between the half-logs, its flagpole ringed with whitewashed stones, its weathered gray dock jutting out into lake prospect with its wooden rope bumpers and its rusty rings for tying up, its prim round floor bed of petunias near the office door must surely have been there always. in truth, it dated only from the first decade of the century. it had been founded by kapi's parents who thought of camping as bracing to the character, like cold showers, and had been passed along to her as an inheritance and an obligation. lois later realized that it must have been a struggle for cappy to keep camp manitou going during the depression and then during the war when money did not flow freely. if it had been a camp for the very rich instead of the merely well-off, there would have been fewer problems. but there must have been enough old girls, ones with daughters, to keep the thing in operation, though not entirely ship-shaped. furniture was battered, painted, trim was peeling, roofs leaked. there were dim photographs of these old girls dotted around the dining hall wearing ample woolen bathing suits and showing off their fat dimpled legs or standing arms intertwined in odd tennis outfits with baggy skirts.
